etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Samuel Hartlib (d. ?1670). From post-classical Latin pansophia universal knowledge from ancient Greek πάνσοϕος clever in every way (from παν- + σοϕός wise) + post-classical Latin -ia

definitions: Universal or encyclopedic knowledge; a scheme, work, or programme attempting to embrace the whole body of human knowledge.

notes.text: Chiefly with reference or allusion to Comenius's scheme for creating a universal encyclopaedia of human knowledge.
